P_or_Q.body:
(a) The question regarding the Prime Minister of France will resolve as Yes if the party of the Prime Minister is not New Popular Front or Together on July 30th, at 12:00 Central European Time, according to credible sources.
(b) The question regarding S&D will resolve as Yes if the S&D holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as No for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both will resolve as Yes. This question resolves on the basis of official statements by the European Parliament or credible media reports.

P.title: Will the Prime Minister of France belong to a coalition other than New Popular Front or Together on July 30, 2024?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if the party of the Prime Minister of France is not New Popular Front or Together on July 30th, at 12:00 Central European Time, according to credible sources.

metadata.background_info:
After a far-right victory in the European elections, French President Emmanuel Macron dissolved the National Assembly, calling snap elections for June 30th and July 7th.

The majority of the 577 districts will [see a runoff](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/french-election-run-off-how-does-it-work-what-look-out-2024-07-05/) on Sunday, July 7, with the most common set of qualified parties being the National Rally-led Union of the Far-Right, centrist Together, and left and center-left New Popular Front. The unprecedented number of three-way runoffs (including *four*-ways in five districts) was boosted by strong turnout, [nearly 20 percentage points more than in 2022](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/strong-turnout-france-high-stakes-elections-support-far-right-grows/); but Together and the NPF guided their third-placed candidates to withdraw to improve the other's chances to beat the far-right, mostly represented by Marine Le Pen's National Rally.

Once the runoff numbers are known for the 17th National Assembly, the question becomes: who will be Prime Minister? The French semi-presidential system gives President Macron political responsibilities, in particular in foreign policy, regardless of the makeup of Parliament; but he must also nominate a Prime Minister, who conducts domestic policy. The government does not need a positive confidence vote from legislators, but it could be subject to a vote of no confidence; current Prime Minister Gabriel Attal's minority government has been relying on case-by-case deals to get legislation approved.

While the far-right has already elected 38 Deputies and made it to the runoff almost everywhere, its surge might still be forestalled by the strategic pact between the center and the left.

Q.title: Will S&D hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the S&D holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.background_info:
The [European Parliament](https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/government_in_ireland/european_government/eu_institutions/european_parliament.html#:~:text=The%20European%20Parliament%20is%20part,member%20states%20every%205%20years.) is a key legislative body within the European Union (EU) that shares lawmaking responsibilities with the Council of the European Union. Comprising [705](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/faq/11/how-many-meps) directly elected Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) from EU member states, the Parliament holds elections every five years. While it cannot initiate legislation, the European Parliament can approve, reject, or amend proposed laws, and it also supervises EU institutions and budgets.

During [European parliamentary elections](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/at-your-service/en/be-heard/elections), candidates run as representatives of their national parties, which are typically affiliated with political groups in the European Parliament. Once elected, Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) officially join political groups based on shared ideologies and policy objectives that align with their national parties. According to the [EU Parliament website](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/about-parliament/en/organisation-and-rules/organisation/political-groups), the following political groups are currently present in the European parliament:

| Group Name | Abbreviation |
|------------|--------------|
| Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) | EPP |
| Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament | S&D |
| Renew Europe Group | RE |
| Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance | Greens/EFA |
| Identity and Democracy Group | ID |
| European Conservatives and Reformists Group | ECR |
| The Left group in the European Parliament  | GUE/NGL |

In the [2019 elections](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/election-results-2019/en), the seats were allocated as follows between the political groups: 

| Group Name | Abbreviation | Seats |
|------------|--------------|-------|
| Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) | EPP | 182 |
| Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament | S&D | 154 |
| Renew Europe Group | RE | 108 |
| Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance | Greens/EFA | 74 |
| Identity and Democracy Group | ID | 73 |
| European Conservatives and Reformists Group | ECR | 62 |
| Non-Inscrits | NI | 57 |
| Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left | GUE/NGL | 41 |
| **Total Seats** | | **751** |


The next European parliamentary elections are [scheduled for 2024](https://multimedia.europarl.europa.eu/en/package/european-elections-2024_23001), with [polling](https://europeelects.eu/ep2024/) indicating a narrow lead for the EPP in early 2023.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Which political group will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections? (S&D)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** for the political group that holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both sub-questions will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

reasons: Both questions pertain to political outcomes in Europe, specifically regarding party coalitions and election results, which could be interconnected in terms of political dynamics and voter behavior.
The outcome of the French Prime Minister's coalition could influence the overall political landscape in Europe, potentially affecting the performance of the S&D party in the elections.
There may be strategic alliances or shifts in voter sentiment that could link the two events, making it relevant to consider their logical combination.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination makes sense given the interconnectedness of European political dynamics and potential influences between the two questions.

metadata.background_info:
The Eurovision Song Contest 2024 is set to take place in Malmö, Sweden, following the country's victory at the 2023 contest. The contest will be held at the Malmö Arena, and will consist of two semi-finals on 7 and 9 May, and a final on 11 May 2024.

Of the 37 participating countries, 6 are guaranteed to participate in the final: The hosting country (Sweden) and the "Big Five" countries (United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Spain). The remaining 31 countries will have to compete in the Semi-finals. In each Semi-final, 10 countries will qualify for the final, and the rest will not.

More information can be found on [Wikipedia](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/21827/countries-in-eurovision-2024-final/)

See also: [How the Eurovision Song Contest works](https://eurovision.tv/about/how-it-works)

P.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

Q.title: Will Russia have control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if, when accessed by Metaculus on June 1, 2024, the [Institute for the Study of War (ISW) map](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/36a7f6a6f5a9448496de641cf64bd375) shows the coordinates 48°35'13.7"N 37°50'02.1"E as under any of the following categories:



- Assessed Russian Advance in Ukraine

- Assessed Russian Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Assessed Russian Control

- Claimed Russian Territory in Ukraine

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Russian control of the location



The question will resolve as **No** if the location is not assessed to be in any of the categories indicating Russian control, which includes but is not limited to:



- Reported Ukrainian Territorial Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Claimed Ukrainian Counteroffensives

- Reported Ukrainian Partisan Warfare

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Ukrainian control of the location or a lack of Russian control of the location

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, or (b) Russia have control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024?
P_or_Q.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following conditions is met:

(a) Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) is greater than 2 and less than or equal to 4 points on July 15, 2024, as reported on the chart accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. A positive value indicates a Trump lead.

(b) The [Institute for the Study of War (ISW) map](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/36a7f6a6f5a9448496de641cf64bd375) shows the coordinates 48°35'13.7"N 37°50'02.1"E as under any categories indicating Russian control (e.g., Assessed Russian Advance, Gains, Control, or Claimed Territory) when accessed by Metaculus on June 1, 2024. The question resolves as **No** if the location is not under Russian control categories.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.background_info:
On June 27, 2024, Joe Biden and Donald Trump held their first debate as part of the campaign for the 2024 presidential election. Biden's debate performance was [widely seen as poor](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-trump-june-debate-poll/), and prompted calls for Biden to drop out, including [from the New York Times editorial board](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/28/opinion/biden-election-debate-trump.html) and, as of July 5, [three House Democrats](https://thehill.com/homenews/house/4755497-seth-moulton-biden-presidential-race/).

The Biden team has reportedly been [taking action](https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/04/politics/biden-rising-tide-pressure-reelection-bid-analysis/index.html) to reverse recent perceptions, and has [so far insisted](https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/4754840-biden-campaign-denies-dropout-rumors/) that Biden will not be dropping out. However, the New York Times [reported](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/03/us/politics/biden-withdraw-election-debate.html) that the Biden team has internally acknowledged that they must turn perceptions around quickly.

According to [538's presidential polling average](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) (when accessed on July 5, 2024), on the date of the debate Trump held a +0.2 percentage point lead in the polling averages, which has since widened to a +2.4 percentage point lead for Trump reported for July 5. The near-term polling trend may be critical as Biden weighs whether to stay in the race ahead of the [2024 Democratic National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Democratic_National_Convention), which is scheduled to be held August 19th through the 22nd.

Q.title: Will Russia have control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if, when accessed by Metaculus on June 1, 2024, the [Institute for the Study of War (ISW) map](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/36a7f6a6f5a9448496de641cf64bd375) shows the coordinates 48°35'13.7"N 37°50'02.1"E as under any of the following categories:



- Assessed Russian Advance in Ukraine

- Assessed Russian Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Assessed Russian Control

- Claimed Russian Territory in Ukraine

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Russian control of the location



The question will resolve as **No** if the location is not assessed to be in any of the categories indicating Russian control, which includes but is not limited to:



- Reported Ukrainian Territorial Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Claimed Ukrainian Counteroffensives

- Reported Ukrainian Partisan Warfare

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Ukrainian control of the location or a lack of Russian control of the location

metadata.background_info: [Reporting suggests](https://www.politico.eu/article/russian-victory-over-ukranian-key-city-chasiv-yar-jeopardize-entire-donetsk-region/) that the Ukrainian military sees the city of Chasiv Yar as strategically significant, and that the capture of the city could jeopardize the remaining key cities in the [Donetsk oblast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donetsk_Oblast). Ukraine has [reportedly said](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/why-is-russia-trying-capture-ukrainian-town-chasiv-yar-2024-04-16/) that Russia aims to capture the city by May 9.

reasons: Both questions pertain to significant geopolitical and electoral events that could influence each other; for example, the outcome of the polling lead may be affected by the public's perception of foreign conflicts and national security issues.
Political events such as elections can shape public opinion on military actions, potentially altering the dynamics of both the election and the conflict in Ukraine.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions makes sense as they are interconnected through the themes of political influence and international relations.

P.title: Did someone intentionally shoot at Trump on July 13th?
P.body:
NYT: "It sounded what could be gun shots interrupted Trump’s rally in Pennsylvania. Trump was hurried off the stage and appeared to be bleeding by his ear."

Resolves YES if someone intentionally shot a bullet or other bullet-like projectile* at Trump on July 13th. Resolves NO if accidental discharge or ricochet caused something to shoot towards Trump.

*I am using bullet-like projectile to mean something that is for all intents and purposes is a bullet but may not technically be a bullet. For example, I would not count a BB gun pellet since it is not plausibly lethal like a bullet would be.

Q.title: Will Francis Suarez be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Francis Suarez is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, [saying at a rally in March 2022](https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-promises-to-return-to-the-white-house-in-2024-2022-3), "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before".  [Early polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.  

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of [June 2022](https://floridapolitics.com/archives/531919-ron-desantis-swats-away-2024-speculation-yet-again/)), though Fox News producers have [called him](https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/08/13/inside-fox-news-desantis-is-the-future-of-the-party-and-hes-taking-advantage/) "the future of the Republican Party".  DeSantis is a frequent [second-place favorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) in polling behind Trump.

Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; [in April 2022](https://archive.ph/uFSD4), when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

All other candidates will resolve as **No**.  This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

reasons: An incident involving Trump being shot at could influence public perception and support for candidates like Francis Suarez, potentially affecting his chances of being the Republican nominee.
Political events, especially involving high-profile figures like Trump, often have ripple effects on the political landscape, including candidate viability and party dynamics.
If Trump were to be injured or incapacitated, it might create an opportunity for other candidates, including Suarez, to gain traction in the nomination race.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is relevant as they both pertain to the political landscape and the implications of events surrounding Trump on the Republican nomination process.

metadata.background_info:
The Eurovision Song Contest 2024 is set to take place in Malmö, Sweden, following the country's victory at the 2023 contest. The contest will be held at the Malmö Arena, and will consist of two semi-finals on 7 and 9 May, and a final on 11 May 2024.

Of the 37 participating countries, 6 are guaranteed to participate in the final: The hosting country (Sweden) and the "Big Five" countries (United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Spain). The remaining 31 countries will have to compete in the Semi-finals. In each Semi-final, 10 countries will qualify for the final, and the rest will not.

More information can be found on [Wikipedia](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/21827/countries-in-eurovision-2024-final/)

See also: [How the Eurovision Song Contest works](https://eurovision.tv/about/how-it-works)

Brazilian pole vaulter Thiago Braz set the Olympic record at 6.03m at the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Olympics. Since then, the world record has risen to 6.24m, set by Swedish athlete Armand Duplantis earlier in 2024.

metadata.background_info:
The most serious attack occurred at the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich, Germany.  Five of the hostage takers were killed, along with eleven members of the Israeli Olympic Team and one West German policeman.
At the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, a bombing at the Centennial Olympic Park resulted in one death and over 100 injuries.  This was classified as domestic terrorism. [Centennial Olympic Park bombing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centennial_Olympic_Park_bombing)
At the 2008 Olympics in Beijing, a knife attack at a Beijing market left [three people dead and over 60 injured]((https://www.start.umd.edu/news/olympics-and-terrorism). Although it did not occur during the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, Korea, the bombing of Korean Air Flight 858 on November 29, 1987 was [considered to be a terrorist attack by North Korea]( https://www.history.com/news/1988-seoul-olympics-north-korea-terrorist-attack) in an attempt to get the Olympics moved from Seoul.

reasons: Both events could be influenced by geopolitical tensions and security conditions, as the situation in Ukraine may affect global security perceptions and counter-terrorism measures in Europe.

Analysts might be interested in understanding the interplay between military control in one region and the potential for terrorist actions in another, especially in a volatile global environment.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the geopolitical context and potential interrelations between military control and terrorism, the logical combination of these questions is worth exploring.

Q.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
Q.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs:

(a) Ron DeSantis is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined solely by the selection of the delegates of the Republican National Convention, not by who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election.

(b) The percentage of votes for Donald Trump in a Manifold poll with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot exceeds that in a poll with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot by 3% or more when both polls close on July 6. The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.

This question will resolve as **Yes** if Ron DeSantis is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, [saying at a rally in March 2022](https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-promises-to-return-to-the-white-house-in-2024-2022-3), "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before".  [Early polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.  

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of [June 2022](https://floridapolitics.com/archives/531919-ron-desantis-swats-away-2024-speculation-yet-again/)), though Fox News producers have [called him](https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/08/13/inside-fox-news-desantis-is-the-future-of-the-party-and-hes-taking-advantage/) "the future of the Republican Party".  DeSantis is a frequent [second-place favorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) in polling behind Trump.

Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; [in April 2022](https://archive.ph/uFSD4), when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

P.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

P_or_Q.body:
(a) This part of the question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) is greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, as reported on the chart for that date, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. Any other candidate being selected will resolve as **No**. P.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.background_info:
On June 27, 2024, Joe Biden and Donald Trump held their first debate as part of the campaign for the 2024 presidential election. Biden's debate performance was [widely seen as poor](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-trump-june-debate-poll/), and prompted calls for Biden to drop out, including [from the New York Times editorial board](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/28/opinion/biden-election-debate-trump.html) and, as of July 5, [three House Democrats](https://thehill.com/homenews/house/4755497-seth-moulton-biden-presidential-race/).

The Biden team has reportedly been [taking action](https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/04/politics/biden-rising-tide-pressure-reelection-bid-analysis/index.html) to reverse recent perceptions, and has [so far insisted](https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/4754840-biden-campaign-denies-dropout-rumors/) that Biden will not be dropping out. However, the New York Times [reported](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/03/us/politics/biden-withdraw-election-debate.html) that the Biden team has internally acknowledged that they must turn perceptions around quickly.

According to [538's presidential polling average](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) (when accessed on July 5, 2024), on the date of the debate Trump held a +0.2 percentage point lead in the polling averages, which has since widened to a +2.4 percentage point lead for Trump reported for July 5. The near-term polling trend may be critical as Biden weighs whether to stay in the race ahead of the [2024 Democratic National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Democratic_National_Convention), which is scheduled to be held August 19th through the 22nd.

P.title: Will Czechia qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
P.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Czechia participates in a Semi-final and is then officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If Czechia does not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

Q.title: Will Albania qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
Q.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Albania participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. The question will resolve as **No** for all other outcomes regarding Albania.

P_or_Q.title: Will either Czechia or Albania qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
P_or_Q.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs: (a) Czechia participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final, or (b) Albania participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. The question will resolve as **No** if neither country qualifies.

metadata.background_info:
The Eurovision Song Contest 2024 is set to take place in Malmö, Sweden, following the country's victory at the 2023 contest. The contest will be held at the Malmö Arena, and will consist of two semi-finals on 7 and 9 May, and a final on 11 May 2024.

Of the 37 participating countries, 6 are guaranteed to participate in the final: The hosting country (Sweden) and the "Big Five" countries (United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Spain). The remaining 31 countries will have to compete in the Semi-finals. In each Semi-final, 10 countries will qualify for the final, and the rest will not.

More information can be found on [Wikipedia](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/21827/countries-in-eurovision-2024-final/)

See also: [How the Eurovision Song Contest works](https://eurovision.tv/about/how-it-works)

Q.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

P_or_Q.title: Will either the CBOE S&P 500 3-Month Volatility Index be higher Year-over-Year on July 20, 2024, or will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
P_or_Q.body: This question will resolve as "Yes" if either of the following occurs: (a) The CBOE S&P 500 3-Month Volatility Index (VXVCLS) is higher on July 20, 2024, than it was on July 20, 2023, based on reporting by the St. Louis Fed: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/VXVCLS. (b) On July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question about Trump will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

Q.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.background_info:
*This question is modeled on [this Metaculus question](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/18606/trump-removed-or-blocked-from-the-ballot/), but asks instead about the possibility of Trump's removal from primary election ballots.*

The 14th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution has a section known as the "Disqualification Clause" or Section 3, which may disqualify individuals from holding federal or state office if they have "engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the [U.S.], or given aid or comfort to the enemies thereof." Given the events surrounding the January 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol, this section has become a subject of considerable debate with respect to former President Donald Trump's eligibility to run for federal office again.

In New Hampshire, Bryant "Corky" Messner, an attorney who ran for U.S. Senate in 2020 with Trump's endorsement, has [expressed intentions to file a legal challenge](https://www.forbes.com/sites/alisondurkee/2023/08/29/trump-14th-amendment-new-hampshire-gop-feuds-as-states-grapple-with-disqualifying-trump-from-ballot/?sh=70038b512e9a) questioning Trump's 2024 candidacy under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The Republican Secretary of State of New Hampshire, David Scanlan, while not actively seeking to remove any candidates, has stated that he will seek legal advice on the issue. Additionally, Michigan’s Democratic Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson has indicated that she will seek a legal opinion on this matter. Voters have also filed lawsuits in Florida and Michigan on the issue. Legal battles are widely expected, and these disputes might reach the U.S. Supreme Court.

This question focuses on whether these and similar ongoing discussions and legal challenges will result in Donald Trump being removed from the primary election ballot of any state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15th, 2024, the planned start of the 2024 Republican National Convention.

reasons: The CBOE S&P 500 3-Month Volatility Index (VXVCLS) reflects market sentiment and uncertainty, which could be influenced by political events such as Trump's potential removal from the ballot.

If Trump is blocked from the primary election ballot, it could lead to increased market volatility due to changes in investor sentiment and political stability, making the combination of these questions relevant for forecasting market behavior.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is worthwhile as both political events and market volatility are interconnected and can influence each other.

This is determined solely by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention. (2) At any point before midnight July 20 Central Time, 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out, as reported by the New York Times. P.title: Will Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
P.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Asa Hutchinson is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently considered; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, [saying at a rally in March 2022](https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-promises-to-return-to-the-white-house-in-2024-2022-3), "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before".  [Early polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.  

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of [June 2022](https://floridapolitics.com/archives/531919-ron-desantis-swats-away-2024-speculation-yet-again/)), though Fox News producers have [called him](https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/08/13/inside-fox-news-desantis-is-the-future-of-the-party-and-hes-taking-advantage/) "the future of the Republican Party".  DeSantis is a frequent [second-place favorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) in polling behind Trump.

Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; [in April 2022](https://archive.ph/uFSD4), when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

P.title: Will Fidesz-KDNP Maintain Its EU Plurality from Hungary in 2024?
P.body: This question will resolve to "Yes" if, following the 2024 European Parliament elections, the Fidesz-KDNP alliance secures more seats than any other single party or coalition, thereby maintaining the highest number of Hungarian seats in the European Parliament, according to credible sources.

metadata.background_info:
The Fidesz-KDNP alliance has long been a dominant political force in Hungary, championed by Viktor Orbán's Fidesz and the Christian Democratic People's Party (KDNP). Since 2005, they have secured a significant majority of Hungary's seats in the European Parliament, capitalizing on shared conservative and nationalistic ideologies. 

However, the alliance faces [new challenges](https://apnews.com/article/hungary-orban-eu-election-magyar-fidesz-russia-f53cd35e52a9f91c34b00d8dd6f85694) as Péter Magyar, a former insider of the Fidesz party, breaks ranks and forms his own party, Tisztelet és Szabadság (Respect and Freedom). Magyar's emergence comes at a time when Fidesz is grappling with scandals and a loss of public trust, highlighted by significant resignations within its ranks.

The 2024 European Parliament elections are critical for the alliance as they face increasing internal and EU-wide challenges, including economic pressures and debates over the EU's influence on national policies. These elections will test the alliance's ability to maintain its influence amid growing political diversity and opposition within Hungary.

Q.title: Will the European Union announce new tariffs or duties on imports of Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024?
Q.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before July 5, 2024, credible sources report that the European Union (EU) has announced that new tariffs or duties will be imposed that would apply to imports of Chinese electric vehicles into the EU.

metadata.background_info:
On May 14, 2024, the Biden administration imposed [new tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles (EVs) and other goods](https://apnews.com/article/biden-china-tariffs-electric-vehicles-evs-solar-2024ba735c47e04a50898a88425c5e2c), with the EV tariffs increasing to a total level of 102.5% from the previous total of 27.5%. [Analysts have suggested](https://www.cnn.com/2024/05/15/business/us-tariffs-ev-europe-china-trade/index.html) that the new tariffs may put pressure on the European Union (EU) to protect its own EV industry, as the US tariffs may effectively close off the US market, making the EU market more attractive to Chinese EV manufacturers.

The [European Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Commission) has been [conducting an anti-subsidy investigation of Chinese EVs](https://www.cnbc.com/2024/04/30/chinese-ev-imports-europe-might-need-to-impose-up-to-55percent-in-tariffs-.html) since [September 2023](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/eu-launches-anti-subsidy-investigation-into-chinese-electric-vehicles-2023-09-13/). The [investigation has a July 4 deadline](https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_23_4752) to impose provisional anti-subsidy duties.

reasons: Both questions pertain to the political and economic landscape of the European Union, which may influence each other.
Changes in trade policy, such as tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles, could affect the political dynamics and electoral outcomes in Hungary, potentially impacting Fidesz-KDNP's performance.
The outcome of the Fidesz-KDNP alliance in the elections may influence the EU's stance on tariffs and duties, as political parties often have differing views on trade policy.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is relevant due to the interconnectedness of political and economic factors within the EU context.

P.title: Will Ron DeSantis be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
P.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Ron DeSantis is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election. It is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

Q.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
Q.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

P_or_Q.title: Will either Ron DeSantis be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, or will a group of at least 5 named Democratic House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
P_or_Q.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs:

(a) Ron DeSantis is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined solely by the selection of the delegates of the Republican National Convention, not by who receives the nomination on the day of the 2024 US election.

(b) A group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members or US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday, July 20th (Pacific Time). This could be by signing a letter or collectively speaking with Biden. All five individuals must be part of the same group message, and reports must confirm their names beyond a reasonable doubt before the market's end date.

If either condition (a) or (b) is met, the question resolves as **Yes**. If neither condition is met, it resolves as **No**.

Q.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Donald Trump is the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, or (b) Trump's lead over Biden is greater than 2 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
P_or_Q.body:
(a) Donald Trump will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election if he is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee. This is determined by the delegates of the Republican National Convention and not by who receives the nomination on the election day.

(b) Trump's lead over Biden will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average if the reported value on the chart for that date shows a Trump lead within that range. A positive value indicates a Trump lead.

P.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
P.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, [saying at a rally in March 2022](https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-promises-to-return-to-the-white-house-in-2024-2022-3), "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before".  [Early polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.  

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of [June 2022](https://floridapolitics.com/archives/531919-ron-desantis-swats-away-2024-speculation-yet-again/)), though Fox News producers have [called him](https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/08/13/inside-fox-news-desantis-is-the-future-of-the-party-and-hes-taking-advantage/) "the future of the Republican Party".  DeSantis is a frequent [second-place favorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) in polling behind Trump.

Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; [in April 2022](https://archive.ph/uFSD4), when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

This question will resolve as **Yes** for the candidate below who is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election.  All other candidates will resolve as **No**.  This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

Q.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.background_info:
On June 27, 2024, Joe Biden and Donald Trump held their first debate as part of the campaign for the 2024 presidential election. Biden's debate performance was [widely seen as poor](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-trump-june-debate-poll/), and prompted calls for Biden to drop out, including [from the New York Times editorial board](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/28/opinion/biden-election-debate-trump.html) and, as of July 5, [three House Democrats](https://thehill.com/homenews/house/4755497-seth-moulton-biden-presidential-race/).

The Biden team has reportedly been [taking action](https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/04/politics/biden-rising-tide-pressure-reelection-bid-analysis/index.html) to reverse recent perceptions, and has [so far insisted](https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/4754840-biden-campaign-denies-dropout-rumors/) that Biden will not be dropping out. However, the New York Times [reported](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/03/us/politics/biden-withdraw-election-debate.html) that the Biden team has internally acknowledged that they must turn perceptions around quickly.

According to [538's presidential polling average](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) (when accessed on July 5, 2024), on the date of the debate Trump held a +0.2 percentage point lead in the polling averages, which has since widened to a +2.4 percentage point lead for Trump reported for July 5. The near-term polling trend may be critical as Biden weighs whether to stay in the race ahead of the [2024 Democratic National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Democratic_National_Convention), which is scheduled to be held August 19th through the 22nd.

reasons: The outcome of the Republican nomination could influence Trump's polling performance against Biden, making it relevant to assess the relationship between these two questions.
Understanding the dynamics of Trump's nomination and polling lead could provide insights into voter sentiment and campaign strategies leading up to the election.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is relevant, as the nomination process and polling metrics are interconnected aspects of the electoral landscape.

P.body:
This market resolves YES if "Borderlands" (2024) receives a B- CinemaScore or higher, and it resolves NO if it receives a C+ or lower. If for some reason a CinemaScore is not reported, this resolves N/A.

"Borderlands" is the adaptation of the hugely popular video game franchise.

Here's a list of CinemaScores for previous video game adaptations.

Q.title: Will "Twisters" (2024) have a Rotten Tomatoes critics score of at least 75%? ("Certified Fresh")
Q.body:
"Twisters" (2024) Rotten Tomatoes page

This resolves YES if the Tomatometer score is 75% or higher, one week after release (July 26th). 

Details 

I will use whatever precision is listed by Rotten Tomatoes (typically an integer percentage, no decimal).

For example, the original "Twister" (1996) currently has a Tomatometer of 63%. This is the equivalent score I will use.

"Certified Fresh" is just used for illustrative purposes (AFAIK, it requires >=75% Tomatometer, but there might be other restrictions—the market resolves solely based on the displayed score).

"Twisters" (2024) is a standalone sequel to the 1996 original, directed by Lee Isaac Chung ("Minari"), starring Glen Powell ("Top Gun: Maverick") and Daisy Edgar Jones ("Normal People").

Q.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
Q.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

P_or_Q.title: Will either Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election or at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
P_or_Q.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs: (a) Asa Hutchinson is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, or (b) a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st.

Details for each component:

(a) Asa Hutchinson must be selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention) as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is regardless of who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by the convention's selection.

(b) At least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party must sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate President Joe Biden early. This includes multiple letters with a combined total of 20 signatures. This must occur before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st.

P.title: Will Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
P.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Asa Hutchinson is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently considered; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, [saying at a rally in March 2022](https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-promises-to-return-to-the-white-house-in-2024-2022-3), "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before".  [Early polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.  

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of [June 2022](https://floridapolitics.com/archives/531919-ron-desantis-swats-away-2024-speculation-yet-again/)), though Fox News producers have [called him](https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/08/13/inside-fox-news-desantis-is-the-future-of-the-party-and-hes-taking-advantage/) "the future of the Republican Party".  DeSantis is a frequent [second-place favorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) in polling behind Trump.

Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; [in April 2022](https://archive.ph/uFSD4), when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

This question will resolve as **Yes** for the candidate below who is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election.  All other candidates will resolve as **No**.  This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.background_info: [The UEFA Champions League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League) (previously known as the European Cup, abbreviated as UCL, or sometimes, UEFA CL) is an annual club association football competition organised by the Union of European Football Associations (UEFA) and contested by top-division European clubs, deciding the competition winners through a round robin group stage to qualify for a double-legged knockout format, and a single leg final. The 2023/24 edition features 32 teams, with the final being played on the 1st of June 2024 at Wembley Stadium.

metadata.background_info:
The Eurovision Song Contest 2024 is set to take place in Malmö, Sweden, following the country's victory at the 2023 contest. The contest will be held at the Malmö Arena, and will consist of two semi-finals on 7 and 9 May, and a final on 11 May 2024.

Of the 37 participating countries, 6 are guaranteed to participate in the final: The hosting country (Sweden) and the "Big Five" countries (United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Spain). The remaining 31 countries will have to compete in the Semi-finals. In each Semi-final, 10 countries will qualify for the final, and the rest will not.

More information can be found on [Wikipedia](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/21827/countries-in-eurovision-2024-final/)

See also: [How the Eurovision Song Contest works](https://eurovision.tv/about/how-it-works)

P.title: Before July 1, 2024, will the International Criminal Court issue arrest warrants for any of the listed Israeli leaders?
P.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if before July 1, 2024, the International Criminal Court (ICC) issues a [warrant of arrest](https://www.icc-cpi.int/about/how-the-court-works) for any of the below listed Israeli cabinet members. It will resolve as **No** otherwise.

* Benjamin Netanyahu (Prime Minister)
* Yoav Gallant (Defense Minister)
* Herzi Halevi (IDF Chief of Staff)

Q.title: Will Israel carry out a deadly attack within Iran before May 1, 2024?
Q.body: This question resolves **Yes** if, following the date of this question's publication and before May 1, 2024, credible reports indicate that an attack attributed to Israel and occurring within Iran's borders has led to the death of at least five individuals.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) The ICC issues arrest warrants for listed Israeli leaders before July 1, 2024, (b) Israel carries out a deadly attack within Iran before May 1, 2024?
P_or_Q.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs:

(a) Before July 1, 2024, the International Criminal Court (ICC) issues a warrant of arrest for any of the listed Israeli cabinet members:
- Benjamin Netanyahu (Prime Minister)
- Yoav Gallant (Defense Minister)
- Herzi Halevi (IDF Chief of Staff)

(b) Following the date of this question's publication and before May 1, 2024, credible reports indicate that an attack attributed to Israel and occurring within Iran's borders has led to the death of at least five individuals.

The question will resolve as **No** if neither of these events occur within their respective timeframes.

P.title: Before July 1, 2024, will the International Criminal Court issue arrest warrants for any of the listed Israeli leaders?
P.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if before July 1, 2024, the International Criminal Court (ICC) issues a [warrant of arrest](https://www.icc-cpi.int/about/how-the-court-works) for any of the below listed Israeli cabinet members. It will resolve as **No** otherwise.

* Benjamin Netanyahu (Prime Minister)
* Yoav Gallant (Defense Minister)
* Herzi Halevi (IDF Chief of Staff)

metadata.background_info:
In April 29, 2024, Axios [reported](https://www.axios.com/2024/04/29/netanyahu-biden-icc-arrest-warrants-war-crimes) that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu asked US President Joe Biden to help prevent the International Criminal Court (ICC) in The Hague from issuing arrest warrants for Israeli cabinet officials stemming from possible allegations of war crimes in Gaza. NBC [reported](https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/israel-fears-icc-issue-arrest-warrants-netanyahu-gaza-war-hamas-rcna149739) that these arrest warrants could come as early as this week, and Israel is working through back channels to try to prevent them from being issued. The US and other G7 countries are [reportedly](https://www.timesofisrael.com/report-several-nations-urging-icc-not-to-issue-arrest-warrants-for-israelis/) campaigning to dissuade the ICC from issuing the warrants so as to avoid jeopardizing a peace deal between Israel and Hamas.

As the ICC [explains](https://www.icc-cpi.int/about/how-the-court-works) on its official website, an arrest warrant is requested by the Prosecutor as part of the investigative stage before trial, especially in cases in which suspects do not appear voluntarily.

The ICC [was founded](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Criminal_Court) in 2002 following the wars in Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia, and it is [intended](https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2024/04/29/icc-israel-warrants-gaza/) as a permanent court to investigate war crimes, genocide and crimes against humanity done by individuals. It issued its first arrest warrants in 2005, and according to the AP [has issued](https://apnews.com/article/israel-hamas-gaza-international-criminal-court-hague-palestinians-1f683a6e2e150d91c415eb1d0a19a44d) a total of 42 arrest warrants. Last year the ICC issued arrest warrants for [Vladimir Putin](https://www.icc-cpi.int/news/situation-ukraine-icc-judges-issue-arrest-warrants-against-vladimir-vladimirovich-putin-and) and one of his government officials stemming from the ICC's investigation into the deportation of Ukrainian children to Russia.

See Also

Base rate information at Wikipedia: [International Criminal Court investigations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Criminal_Court_investigations)

Q.title: Will Israel carry out a deadly attack within Iran before May 1, 2024?
Q.body: This question resolves **Yes** if, following the date of this question's publication and before May 1, 2024, credible reports indicate that an attack attributed to Israel and occurring within Iran's borders has led to the death of at least five individuals.

metadata.background_info: In a significant escalation of regional tensions, [Iran launched a coordinated aerial attack targeting Israeli territory on April 13, 2024](https://www.wsj.com/world/middle-east/iran-tries-to-calibrate-response-against-israel-after-deadly-bombing-abb38b57). This action by Iran came as a direct retaliation for an [Israeli airstrike earlier in the month](https://apnews.com/article/israel-syria-airstrike-iranian-embassy-edca34c52d38c8bc57281e4ebf33b240#:~:text=An%20Israeli%20airstrike%20in%20a,at%20least%20five%20Iranian%20advisers.), which struck the Iranian Embassy complex in Damascus, Syria, which resulted in the deaths of seven Iranian officers, including three high-ranking commanders, intensifying Iran's resolve to respond.

reasons: Both questions relate to geopolitical tensions in the Middle East, particularly involving Israel and its military actions.
An arrest warrant from the ICC could potentially influence Israel's military strategy or decisions regarding attacks, making the two events interrelated.
Understanding the interplay between international legal actions and military operations can provide insights into the broader implications of these events.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is relevant and worth considering due to their interconnectedness in the context of international relations and military actions.

P.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.background_info:
On June 27, 2024, Joe Biden and Donald Trump held their first debate as part of the campaign for the 2024 presidential election. Biden's debate performance was [widely seen as poor](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-trump-june-debate-poll/), and prompted calls for Biden to drop out, including [from the New York Times editorial board](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/28/opinion/biden-election-debate-trump.html) and, as of July 5, [three House Democrats](https://thehill.com/homenews/house/4755497-seth-moulton-biden-presidential-race/).

The Biden team has reportedly been [taking action](https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/04/politics/biden-rising-tide-pressure-reelection-bid-analysis/index.html) to reverse recent perceptions, and has [so far insisted](https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/4754840-biden-campaign-denies-dropout-rumors/) that Biden will not be dropping out. However, the New York Times [reported](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/03/us/politics/biden-withdraw-election-debate.html) that the Biden team has internally acknowledged that they must turn perceptions around quickly.

According to [538's presidential polling average](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) (when accessed on July 5, 2024), on the date of the debate Trump held a +0.2 percentage point lead in the polling averages, which has since widened to a +2.4 percentage point lead for Trump reported for July 5. The near-term polling trend may be critical as Biden weighs whether to stay in the race ahead of the [2024 Democratic National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Democratic_National_Convention), which is scheduled to be held August 19th through the 22nd.

Q.title: Will Biden drop out before July 20?
Q.body: If Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20 midnight Eastern Time, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, this market will resolve to no.

content.text: If Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20 midnight Eastern Time, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, this market will resolve to no.

reasons: The probability of Biden dropping out could be influenced by his polling performance, including whether Trump has a narrow lead or not. If Trump is leading significantly, Biden may be more likely to consider dropping out.
Both questions concern the dynamics of the 2024 presidential election, making their combination relevant to understanding the overall electoral landscape.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is relevant as they both pertain to the same electoral context and could influence each other.

P.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
P.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

Q.title: Will there be another Democratic party presidential debate?
Q.body: Resolves YES if there is a debate between potential Democratic nominees (e.g. Harris, Newsom, Whitmer, Biden etc.) prior to the 2024 Democratic National Convention. Resolves NO otherwise.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024? (b) Another Democratic party presidential debate occur before the 2024 Democratic National Convention?
P_or_Q.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if either of the following conditions is met:

(a) Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as of July 15, 2024. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

(b) There is a debate between potential Democratic nominees (e.g., Harris, Newsom, Whitmer, Biden, etc.) prior to the 2024 Democratic National Convention. The question resolves as "No" if there is no such debate before the convention.

P.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. metadata.background_info:
*This question is modeled on [this Metaculus question](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/18606/trump-removed-or-blocked-from-the-ballot/), but asks instead about the possibility of Trump's removal from primary election ballots.*

The 14th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution has a section known as the "Disqualification Clause" or Section 3, which may disqualify individuals from holding federal or state office if they have "engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the [U.S.], or given aid or comfort to the enemies thereof." Given the events surrounding the January 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol, this section has become a subject of considerable debate with respect to former President Donald Trump's eligibility to run for federal office again.

In New Hampshire, Bryant "Corky" Messner, an attorney who ran for U.S. Senate in 2020 with Trump's endorsement, has [expressed intentions to file a legal challenge](https://www.forbes.com/sites/alisondurkee/2023/08/29/trump-14th-amendment-new-hampshire-gop-feuds-as-states-grapple-with-disqualifying-trump-from-ballot/?sh=70038b512e9a) questioning Trump's 2024 candidacy under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The Republican Secretary of State of New Hampshire, David Scanlan, while not actively seeking to remove any candidates, has stated that he will seek legal advice on the issue. Additionally, Michigan’s Democratic Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson has indicated that she will seek a legal opinion on this matter. Voters have also filed lawsuits in Florida and Michigan on the issue. Legal battles are widely expected, and these disputes might reach the U.S. Supreme Court.

This question focuses on whether these and similar ongoing discussions and legal challenges will result in Donald Trump being removed from the primary election ballot of any state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15th, 2024, the planned start of the 2024 Republican National Convention.
